practice. They do everything from allowing us to walk to keeping our blood 
flowing! 
Some muscles are known as “voluntary” -- that is, they only work when we 
specifically tell them to. When we say something, swing a bat, or clap our hands, 
these are voluntary movements. Others like the contracting of the heart, the movement of the diaphragm so that we can breathe, or blinking of our eyes is automatic. These muscles move through signals from the nerves, and, in some 
cases, the brain, as well. 
Nervous System and the Brain
The nervous system controls the different organs and functions of the body.  It 
works all the time to keep us alive. There are two major divisions of the nervous system: 
✱ The central nervous system 
✱ The peripheral nervous system 
The central nervous system consists of the brain and the spinal cord. The brain lies within the skull and controls body functions by sending and receiving messages through the spinal cord.
